{{Infobox person | name = Sattar Khan | image = Sattar khan.jpg | birth_date = October 20, 1866 | birth_place = [[Tabriz]], [[Qajar dynasty|Persia]] | death_date = November 9, 1914 (aged 48) | death_place = [[Tehran]], [[Qajar dynasty|Persia]] | burial_place = [[Shah-Abdol-Azim shrine]], [[Tehran]] | nationality = | party = [[Moderate Socialists Party]]<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.ensani.ir/storage/Files/20100929093126-453.pdf|title= حزب اجتماعیون اعتدالیون از پیدایش تا فروپاشی|language=Persian|author=Ali Mohammadi|number=53–56|page=433|journal=Yad|year=1378}}</ref> | spouse = Fatemeh | children = Yadollah, Soltan, Masoumeh }}
'''Sattar Khan''' ({{lang-fa|ستارخان}}, {{IPA-fa|sætːɒːɾ xɒn|IPA}}, October 20, 1866 – November 17, 1914), honorarily titled '''Sardār-e Melli''' ({{lang-fa|سردار ملی}} meaning ''National Commander'') was a pivotal figure in the [[Iranian Constitutional Revolution]] and is considered a national hero.<ref>http://www.iranchamber.com/history/sattarkhan/sattar_khan.php</ref>
==Biography== ===Early life=== Sattar Khan was born in [[Tabriz]], of [[Iranian Azerbaijani]] origin,<ref>Iran and Its Place Among Nations, by Alidad Mafinezam, Aria Mehrabi, 2008, p.57</ref><ref>Encyclopedia of the Peoples of Africa and the Middle East, Facts on File, Incorporated, 2009 p.78</ref><ref>The Turks in World History, by Carter Vaughn Findley - Professor of History Ohio State University, 2004, p.146</ref> some time in 1868. He was the third son of Haj Hasan Bazzaz, from the [[Arasbārān|Qaradagh]]. During his childhood, his eldest brother, who had become a highway robber, was executed by the authorities.<ref>http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/sattar-khan-one-of-the-most-popular-heroes-from-tabriz-who-defended-the-town-during-the-lesser-autocracy-in-1908-09</ref>
The family later moved to [[Tabriz]] where Sattar himself came into conflict with the law when he tried to find a hideout for two Caucasian fugitives to whom his father had given shelter. He was incarcerated for two years in Narin Qalʿa, a notorious local prison. Afterwards he too became a brigand and was subsequently imprisoned again. He also served in the gendarmerie controlling the main road between Khoy and Marand, and for a while found employment as part of the armed escort to the crown prince [[Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar|Mozaffar-al-Din Mirza]] and was given the title of "khan" (which means "sir" in the [[Persian language]]).<ref>http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/sattar-khan-one-of-the-most-popular-heroes-from-tabriz-who-defended-the-town-during-the-lesser-autocracy-in-1908-09</ref>
Later, after a period in Tehran, he headed an auxiliary troop fighting [[Turkmen people|Turkmen]] highway robbers near [[Mashhad]].<ref>http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/sattar-khan-one-of-the-most-popular-heroes-from-tabriz-who-defended-the-town-during-the-lesser-autocracy-in-1908-09</ref>
===Revolutionary=== Sattar Khan had close ties to the [[Social Democratic Party (Persia)|Social Democratic Party]].<ref>Shaffer, Brenda (2003). Borders and Brethren: Iran and the Challenge of Azerbaijani Identity. MIT Press. p. 41. {{ISBN|0-262-19477-5}}</ref> He rose from obscurity to head [[Iranian Constitutional Revolution|Constitutionalist rebels]] from the [[Amirkhiz]] district of [[Tabriz]]. By 1907, he had become a favored leader of the rebels. After shelling the [[Majles]] (parliament) of Iran in the capital [[Tehran]], 40 thousand of [[Mohammad Ali Shah]]'s soldiers were ordered to attack Tabriz, where Constitutional rebels were holding out. In June 1908, under the leadership of Sattar Khan, a High Military Council was established. Sattar Khan was appointed the Commander in chief of High Council, [[Bagher Khan]] as his deputy, and Ali Musyo, Haji Ali and Seyed Hashem Khan as other notable members.
[[File:Sattar khan and Bagir khan.jpg|thumb|Sattar Khan and [[Baqer Khan]]]]
By April 1909, the Tabriz rebels had lost a large number of their fighters in driving out royalist forces from the city. Taking into account Sattar Khan and [[Bagher Khan]]'s heroism during the battle, Sattar Khan was honored by the title of "Sardar-e Melli" ({{lang|fa|سردار ملی}}, "National General") and Bagir khan "Salar-e Melli" ({{lang|fa|سالار ملی}}, "National Leader") by the order of the Assembly.
The early victories of the rebels in Tabriz greatly influenced other Constitutionalists across Iran. Special committees with the name of "Sattar Khan" were established in [[Tehran]], [[Rasht]], [[Qazvin]], [[Isfahan]] and other cities. Sattar Khan's reputation also led to the powerful [[Bakhtiari people|Bakhtiyari]] tribal leaders to throw in their lot with the Tabriz rebels.<ref>Arash Khazeni, ''Tribes & empire on the margins of nineteenth-century Iran'', University of Washington Press, 2009. (p. 172)</ref>
[[File:Sattar Khan.jpg|thumb|left|Portrait photograph of Sattar Khan with his rifle.]]
Most of the cities of Azarbaijan province were cleared of royalist military forces by October 1908. [[Mohammad Ali Shah]] authorized the reopening of the Majles in Tehran in order to try and placate the opposition.
The Second Majles was held in December 1908. It ordered a plaque of honor with images of Sattar Khan and Bagher Khan carved on it in gold as a token of appreciation for their services.
The strengthening of revolutionary power in the wake of the Tabriz victory frightened not only the [[Qajar]] [[Shah]] but also his allies, Russia and Great Britain. In March 1910, Sattar Khan and Bagher Khan set out for the capital Tehran with 300 pro-[[Moderate Socialists Party|Moderates]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Abrahamian|first=Ervand|author-link=Ervand Abrahamian|year=1982|title=Iran Between Two Revolutions|isbn=0-691-10134-5|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|pages=107}}</ref> soldiers, where they were greeted by large numbers of supporters April 3, 1910.
Sattar Khan and his warrior camped out in [[Atabey Park|Atabek Park]], where they refused to obey the Shah's order to disarm. The Shah's troops and police forces led by [[Yeprem Khan|Yeprem Khan (Davidyans)]], head of Tehran police, launched a brief but violent confrontation on the night of August 7, 1910, and succeeded in surrounding and disarming Sattar Khan's forces. About 30 warriors were killed and Sattar Khan was wounded in his leg – remaining disabled until his death at the age 48, on November 9, 1914.<ref>Houri Berberian, ''Armenians and the Iranian constitutional revolution of 1905-1911: "the love for freedom has no fatherland"'', Westview Press, 2001. (p. 154).</ref> He was buried in the famous [[Shah-Abdol-Azim shrine]] cemetery in [[Shahr-e Ray]], just outside Tehran.
==Legacy== Sattar Khan is remembered in Iran as heroic leader of the [[Iranian Constitutional Revolution]] and is the subject of poems and songs.

[[File:Stefan P Kruszewski MD.jpg|thumb|Stefan P. Kruszewski, M.D., May 2011]] '''Stefan Philip Kruszewski''' is an American [[psychiatrist|clinical]] and [[forensic psychiatrist]], active as a whistleblower in medically related cases.<ref name="Voreacos">Voreacos, David and Margaret Cronin Fisk. AstraZeneca Case Rewards Repeat Whistleblowers With $45 Million [Online]. Bloomberg, L.P. 13 May 2010[Accessed 18 Jul 2011]. Available at: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-05-12/astrazeneca-s-520-million-u-s-settlement-rewards-repeat-whistleblowers.html</ref> He is principal in the company which bears his name, Stefan P. Kruszewski, M.D. & Associates, P.C. in [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania]].<ref name="Conflicting">{{cite news|author=Kruszewski, SP|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Health/medical-conflicts-interest-disaster-patients/story?id=13060973|title=Doctors' Conflicting Interests Can Cost Money and Lives, and Hinder Medical Discoveries|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=March 28, 2011|accessdate=November 18, 2018}} ABC News.com: Health: Wellness. Available from ABC World News</ref>
==Career== ===Psychiatrist=== A graduate of [[Princeton University]] and [[Harvard Medical School]], Kruszewski has over 30 years of clinical and teaching experience in the field of psychiatry, with particular focus on addictionology, [[neuropsychiatry]] and [[neuropharmacology]].<ref>Kruszewski's complete resume: {{cite web|url=http://www.spkmd.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=23&Itemid=40|date=March 27, 2012|title=Archived copy|accessdate=2011-07-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120327005420/http://www.spkmd.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=23&Itemid=40|archivedate=March 27, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Fitzharris, Dustin|url=https://www.advocate.com/news/news-features/2011/05/26/stefan-kruszewski-problem-pot|title=The Problem with Pot|work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]|date=May 26, 2011|accessdate=November 18, 2018}}</ref>
Kruszewski is a [[forensic science|forensic]] specialist and has worked with both [[plaintiff]] and [[defense (legal)|defense]] [[lawsuit|litigation]]. He has testified as an [[expert witness]]<ref>[http://www.lawjournaltv.com/documents/t3-LJT_MCS_Youre_in_good_company.pdf You're in Good Company] Law Journal Television. Retrieved July 18, 2011.</ref> in a range of cases involving [[antipsychotic|antipsychotic medications]]<ref name="Weinstein">[http://www.leagle.com/xmlResult.aspx?xmldoc=2007719489FSupp2d230_1689.xml&docbase=CSLWAR3-2007-CURR Weinstein. Memorandum, Order, & Judgment. Zyprexa Products Liability Litigation. Monty Souther, Robert Cusella, Judith New, Beverly Pearson, Donna Worthington v Eli Lilly & Company. Nos. 04-MD-1596, 06-CV-1729. US District Court, Eastern District, New York. 489 F. Supp.2d 230 (2007)].</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Pringle, Evelyn|title=Zyprexa Injury Clock Keeps Ticking Away|url=https://www.sott.net/articles/show/126548-Zyprexa+Injury+Clock+Keeps+Ticking+Away|website=Scott.net|date=February 1, 2007|accessdate=November 18, 2018}}</ref>), [[antidepressant|antidepressant medications]],<ref name="USvHampson">State of New York v. Brandon W. Hampson, No. 2006NA021294, N.Y. Dist., 1st Dist., Nassau Co.; 2009 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2182</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Mitev, Vesselin|url=https://www.law.com/almID/1202433728708/|title=Antidepressant Withdrawal Is Blamed for Assault|journal=New York Law Journal|date=September 11, 2009|accessdate=November 18, 2018}}</ref><ref>Michelle P. LaBaer v Pfizer, Inc. No.294236V. Circuit Court for Montgomery County Maryland.</ref> [[analgesic|analgesic medications]] (including [[opioid]]s),<ref name="Voreacos"/><ref>Daniel B. Timmons v The Purdue Pharma Company; Purdue Pharma LP; The Purdue Frederick Company; The P.F. Laboratories Inc.; The Abbott Laboratories; Abbott Laboratories, Inc. and Mallinckdrodt Inc. 8:04-CV-1479-T-26MAP. US District Court for the Middle District of Florida.</ref> and a range of [[mental disorder|psychiatric illnesses]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/pa-commonwealth-court/1426141.html|title=Brobst v Workers Compensation Appeal Board Schuylkill Products Inc|date=May 23, 2003|accessdate=November 18, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/2007-08-26-stuttering_N.htm|author=Keen, Judy|title=Legal Battle Ends Over Stuttering Experiment|work=[[USA Today]]|date=August 26, 2007|accessdate=November 18, 2018}}</ref> Kruszewski has been recognized as a "distinguished expert" by [[senior status|senior]] [[federal judge]], [[Jack B. Weinstein|the Honorable Jack B. Weinstein]], [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York]] (June 2007).<ref name="Weinstein"/> He has been recognized as a psychiatric expert by [[Patti B. Saris|the Honorable Patti B. Saris]] and testified in the Federal Daubert hearings in US District Court of Massachusetts (May 2009).<ref>Saris, USDJ. "In Re Neurontin Marketing, Sales Practices, and Products Liability Litigation: This Document Relates to: All Products Liability Actions" Mdl No 1629 Civ Action No 04-10981-PBS (United States District Court, District of Massachusetts)</ref> Honorable Judge Rhonda E. Fischer has also accepted and affirmed expert testimony by Kruszewski in the Frye Hearings in District Court of the County of Nassau, New York State (Jan-May 2009).<ref name="USvHampson"/><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.lexisnexis.com/documents/pdf/20091112090115_large.pdf|title=New York Judge Allows Zoloft Causation Opinion In Defense of Assault Charges|journal=Mealey's Daubert Report|date=September 2009|volume=13|issue=9|page=19}}</ref>
===Fraud investigator=== As a fraud investigator for the [[Pennsylvania|Commonwealth of Pennsylvania]] in 2003, Kruszewski uncovered the abuse and medical mistreatment of children and the mentally ill in [[residential treatment center]]s, and was eventually fired for trying to expose what he had discovered.<ref name="Waters">Waters, Rob. "Medicating Aliah." Mother Jones. May/June 2005 Issue. Available at: http://motherjones.com/politics/2005/05/medicating-aliah</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://psychintegrity.org/storage/newsletter3-pub.pdf|author=Jankovich, Delores|title=Important Highlights of the 2006 ICSPP Conference|journal=ICSPP Newsletter|publisher=ICSPP|year=2006|number=4|pages=3-4}}</ref> Kruszewski brought suit for [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] claims against the [[Pennsylvania Department of Public Welfare]] and in June 2007 he was awarded a settlement.<ref name="FAsettlement">Stefan P. Kruszewski v Pfizer Inc., et al. Settlement Agreement. No. 04-1420 (United States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania</ref> Also resulting, Kruszewski filed his first Qui tam lawsuit which settled in 2009 against Southwood Psychiatric Hospital.<ref>{{cite web|author=Hartman, Patty|publisher=United States Attorney's Office|location=Eastern District, Pennsylvania|date=April 22, 2009|accessdate=November 18, 2018|url=https://www.justice.gov/archive/usao/pae/News/2009/apr/southwoodrelease.pdf|title=U.S. Attorney Announces First Settlement Involving Psychiatric Residential Treatment Facilities}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://au.sys-con.com/node/933956|author=Marketwired|title=Fish & Richardson and the U.S. Department of Justice Settle Medicaid Fraud and Abuse Case at Southwood Psychiatric Hospital in Pennsylvania|publisher=SYS-CON Publications, Inc|date=April 23, 2009|accessdate=November 18, 2018}}</ref>
He has been a relator in two additional successful [[Qui tam]] lawsuits: the first against [[Pfizer]] for its drug [[Valdecoxib|Bextra]] which settled in October 2009,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/03/business/03health.html|title=Pfizer Pays $2.3 Billion to Settle Marketing Case|work=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=September 2, 2009|accessdate=November 18, 2018}}</ref><ref>[https://www.justice.gov/sites/default/files/usao-ma/legacy/2012/10/09/Pfizer%20Settlement%20Agreement.pdf Settlement Agreement Between United States and Pfizer, Inc.] August 2009.</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/8234533.stm|publisher=[[BBC News]]|title=Pfizer agrees record fraud fine|date=September 9, 2009|accessdate=November 18, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Howard">{{cite news|url=https://www.theday.com/article/20091004/BIZ02/310049957|author=Howard, Lee|title=Lawsuit hits credibility of Pfizer drug and research|work=[[The Day (New London)|The Day]]|publisher=The Day Publishing Company.|date=October 4, 2009|accessdate=November 18, 2018}}</ref> and the second against [[AstraZeneca]] for its drug [[Quetiapine|Seroquel]] which settled in April 2010.<ref name="Voreacos"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/behind-two-big-drug-company-settlements-professional-whistleblowers/|author=Jim Edwards|title=Behind Two Big Drug Company Settlements: Professional Whistleblowers|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=April 28, 2010|accessdate=November 18, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Deming">{{cite web|author=Deming, Tavy and Brian Kenney|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2010/04/prweb3937374.htm|title=AstraZeneca Pays $520 Million to Settle Seroquel Whistleblower Claims|publisher=PRWeb|date=April 28, 2010|accessdate=November 18, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Wilson, Duff|title=Side Effects May Include Lawsuits|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/03/business/03psych.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=October 2, 2010|accessdate=November 18, 2018}}</ref>
===Whistleblower=== Kruszewski is a three-time successful [[whistleblower]], with settlements from suits brought against Southwood Psychiatric Hospital, Pfizer, Inc., and AstraZeneca. Kruszewski became aware of inadequate care and the exploiting of state-committed mentally ill children through overmedication and physical and [[chemical restraint]]s while working for the Department of Public Welfare, Bureau of Program Integrity for the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. When he refused to keep silent about his discoveries, he was fired from his position at the state.<ref>Stefan P. Kruszewski v Pfizer Inc., et al. No. 04-1420 (United States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania</ref> Kruszewski won settlements for both a First Amendment case against the state of Pennsylvania<ref name="FAsettlement" /> as well as his first Qui tam lawsuit against the hospital.<ref>United States of America ex rel. Stefan P. Kruszewski v Southwood Psychiatric Hospital; and Youth and Family Centered Services, Inc. a/k/a YFCS, Inc. Civil Action No. 05-1839 (Eastern District Pennsylvania)</ref> In the cases against pharmaceutical giants, Pfizer<ref>United States et al. ex rel. Stefan Kruszewski v. Pfizer, Inc., Civ. No. 07-4106 (Eastern District Pennsylvania)</ref> and AstraZeneca,<ref name="AstraZeneca case">United States of America ex rel. Stefan Kruszewski v. AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals LP, Civil Action No. 06-4004 (Eastern District Pennsylvania)</ref> Kruszewski highlighted clinical science that was misrepresented by the defendants in their marketing and promotion of certain drugs. He also demonstrated problems with off-label marketing (marketing that promotes uses, patients or doses that are not approved by the [[Food and Drug Administration|US FDA]]) which resulted in heightened, but often non-transparent, risk to the health of patients and exceptional costs to taxpayers and state and federal governments.<ref name="Howard"/><ref name="Deming"/>

{{Use British English|date=December 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox book | name = The Twits | image = The Twits first edition.jpg | caption = First edition | author = [[Roald Dahl]] | illustrator = [[Quentin Blake]] | cover_artist = Quentin Blake | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = | genre = [[Children's literature|Children's novel]] | publisher = [[Jonathan Cape]] (London) | pub_date = 1980 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|hardback]], [[paperback]]) | pages =270

'''''The Twits''''' is a humorous children's book written by [[Roald Dahl]] and illustrated by [[Quentin Blake]]. It was written in 1979, and first published in 1980. ''The Twits'' was adapted for the stage in November 2007.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/lancashire/content/articles/2007/11/16/november_twits_feature.shtml "The Twits hit Lancaster!"]. BBC. Retrieved 3 June 2012</ref>
==Overview== {{Expand section|date=July 2017}} The idea of ''The Twits'' was triggered by Dahl's desire to "do something against beards", because he had an acute hatred of them. The first sentence of the story is, "What a lot of hairy-faced men there are around nowadays!"
==Plot== A hideous, vindictive, spiteful couple known as the Twits live together in a brick house without windows (Mr. Twit reasons that this stops people looking in on them, not taking into account that windows are intended to be used for looking ''out'' rather than ''in''). They continuously play nasty practical jokes on each other out of hatred for one another, ranging from Mr. Twit hiding a frog in his wife's bed that he claims is a monster to Mrs. Twit tricking her husband into eating worms in spaghetti.
They also keep a family of pet monkeys, the Muggle-Wumps. The Twits, who are retired circus trainers, are trying to form the first upside down monkey circus, leaving the monkeys to stand on their heads for hours on end. If they fail to do what Mr. Twit says, Mrs. Twit beats them with her cane.
Mr. Twit also coats tree limbs with [[Birdlime|a strong sticky]] [[glue]] in hopes of catching birds for Mrs. Twit to make into a bird pie. The monkeys try to warn the birds, but since the monkeys speak in an African language, the English birds cannot understand them, so the poor birds wind up boiling in Mrs. Twit's pie.
One week, the Roly-Poly bird flies in from Africa to visit the monkeys, and acting as an interpreter of languages, keeps the birds from sitting anywhere Mr. Twit has spread glue. Mr. Twit tries several times to catch the birds, spreading the glue on an increasing number of perches, but the Roly-Poly bird changes his warning to reflect the new traps. Tired of chasing the birds, the Twits decide to buy guns to kill them.
The Muggle-Wumps, tired of being forced to stand on their heads, with the help of the birds use Mr. Twit's powerful glue to attach the couple's furniture to their ceiling while they are away to trick them into thinking that they are upside-down and that their ceiling is actually their floor. The birds also smear glue on the Twits' heads, which permanently fixes them to the ground when a panicked Mr. Twit suggests that they stand on their heads so that they are 'the right way up' after they first walk into the upside down living room.
Stuck on their heads with all their weight pressing down on them, they catch the "Dreaded Shrinks" (a disease that Mr. Twit had convinced Mrs. Twit that she had earlier in the book as one of the aforementioned pranks), their bodies compressing 'downwards' so that they eventually shrink away into nothing, leaving the Muggle-Wumps free to escape.
===Mr. Twit=== Mr. Twit is a wicked person, having hair that covers his entire face, with the exception of his forehead, eyes, and nose. His hair (which he falsely believes makes him appear "wise and grand" but is widely agreed by everyone else makes him look like a twit), is spiky and hard. Because he never washes it, his mustache holds scraps of food stuck there while he ate, including tinned sardines, Stilton cheese, and corn flakes.
Occasionally, he licks these scraps out and eats them when he is hungry. Instead of wiping his mouth with a cloth, Mr. Twit simply wipes it on his sleeve. Mr. Twit is an alcohol drinker with a fondness for beer, he even drinks at breakfast. He is known to seem very quiet when he is plotting. He and his wife mistreat their monkeys, the Muggle-Wumps. They have kept Muggle-Wump and his family locked up in a cage in the garden.
===Mrs. Twit=== Mrs. Twit is the hideously ugly, menacing wife of Mr. Twit, whose former beauty was distorted as a result of constant horrible thoughts over time. She takes advantage of her [[glass eye]] to play [[practical jokes]] in revenge against her husband, and demonstrates multiple acts of cruelty and viciousness throughout the story; it has been mentioned that the main reason behind her use of a walking cane was as a weapon against innocent children and animals, she participates in the torment of the couple's pet monkeys the Muggle-Wumps, and serves Mr. Twit a lunch of worms disguised as [[spaghetti]].
Albeit, while she frequently demonstrates acts of stupidity, she has also exhibited intelligence; she managed to maneuver her way out of a prank that ended with her being carried off into the sky by balloons by chewing through several of the strings and landing safely on the ground. However, aside from this, she is portrayed as being hideous, cruel, and unhygienic.
==The Tricks== A series of pranks advance the [[plot (narrative)|plot]] of the story. Brief descriptions appear below:
===The Glass-Eye=== Mrs. Twit removes her glass eye and drops it in his beer mug while he isn't looking. It isn't until he empties said mug that he sees the eye sitting in there, startling him something awful. Mrs. Twit laughs, gloating that this proves she is always watching him.
===The Frog=== In revenge for the glass eye trick, Mr. Twit places a [[frog]] in Mrs. Twit's [[bed]], and frightens Mrs. Twit by claiming the item in her bed is a 'Giant Skillywiggler', with "teeth like screwdrivers" with which it would bite off her [[toes]]. Mrs. Twit then faints, at which point Mr. Twit splashes a jugful of cold water onto her face. She soon recovers, as the [[frog]] hops onto her [[face]] to get near the [[water]].
Mr. Twit then claims the 'Giant Skillywiggler' will soon bite off her nose. Mrs. Twit then flees.
===The Wormy Spaghetti=== Seeking revenge for the Frog Trick, Mrs. Twit places [[worm]]s from the [[garden]] in cooked spaghetti, which Mr. Twit eats, being re-assured by Mrs. Twit that it is merely a new kind called "Squiggly Spaghetti" she has recently bought. When he has eaten it, Mrs. Twit joyfully reveals the truth, to Mr. Twit's horror and disgust.
===The Shrinks=== In revenge for the Wormy Spaghetti, Mr. Twit glues pieces of wood no thicker than a penny onto Mrs. Twit's [[Walking stick|cane]] each night, as well as onto the legs of her [[chair]], making Mrs. Twit believe that she is slowly shrinking.
Mr. Twit then frightens her by claiming that she has contracted an illness called the 'shrinks', by which she will be caused to disappear. Mr. Twit then claims that to cure the shrinks, Mrs. Twit will have to be "stretched". Mr. Twit then ties Mrs. Twit up in the garden to 60 gas balloons intending to leave her there for a while to teach her a lesson.
However, once Mrs. Twit makes the mistake of saying that if the strings break, it's goodbye for her, Mr. Twit pretends to tie some more strings to her ankles, before cutting through the strings and sending her skywards. Mrs. Twit eventually returns by biting through several of the balloon strings so she sinks slowly down, eventually collapsing on Mr. Twit in the garden and beating him senseless with her long walking stick immediately afterwards.
===The Sticky Tree=== There is a "Big Dead Tree" in the Twits' [[garden]], which Mr. Twit uses to trap [[bird]]s by spreading Hug-Tight Sticky [[Glue]] on the branches. Captive birds are then made into a [[pie]] by Mrs. Twit. During the story four schoolboys are caught instead of birds; but escape by unfastening their trousers and falling to the ground outside the Twits' garden after Mr. Twit said that he will make boy pie instead of bird pie. It is this use of glue that gives the captive [[monkey]] [[Muggle-Wump]] and his family the idea of using it against the Twits.
===Rescuing the Animals=== Using their friend the Roly-Poly Bird as an interpreter of languages, Muggle-Wump and his wife and children convey the warning that any bird landing on the Big Dead Tree will be cooked into Mrs. Twit's Bird Pie. When Mr. Twit, in retaliation, spreads glue on the monkeys' cage (which serves as a substitute perch), the monkeys alter the warning. The birds end up landing on the Twits' roof.
This enrages Mr. Twit, who doesn't want to keep waiting for his pie, so the Twits decide to go to the shop and buy a [[gun]] each. During their absence on this errand, Muggle-Wump plots a final trick: to turn the Twits' house upside down. With the help of the birds, Muggle-Wump removes the carpet from the floor, as well as all of the tables, chairs, and other objects in the house, and uses Mr. Twit's glue to stick the objects upside down to the ceiling, leaving the floor absolutely bare.
By doing this, the Twits will believe that they have been turned upside-down, as they will be standing on what looks like the ceiling of their house, and will stand on their heads to be the right way up. To keep their heads glued to the ground, two birds will put a small amount of glue on the Twits' heads right before they enter the house, so that when they stand on their heads, they will be stuck.
Just as the preparations for this trick are finished, the twits return home. Everything goes as planned, the Twits believed they've been turned upside down and so stand on their heads to counter it, only to be stuck to the bare floor. However, heads are not made to be stood upon. With so much weight on it from above, the Twits literally get 'the shrinks', as was mentioned earlier in the book. However, this time it's not a trick, it's the real thing. After a week or so, the Twits disappear, and everyone who knew of them shouts "hooray!"
Meanwhile, The Muggle-wumps and Roly-Poly bird escape to their native African land.
==Film== Since February 2003, a feature film adaptation of the book has been in development by [[Vanguard Animation]] and its founder [[John H. Williams]]. As part of multi picture deal with [[Walt Disney Pictures]], Vanguard was set to produce a CG animated/live action film, with [[John Cleese]] and [[Kirk DeMicco]] writing the screenplay.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brodesser|first=Claude|title='Twits' pic pleases Cleese|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117880020|accessdate=21 January 2012|newspaper=Variety|date=4 February 2003}}</ref>
In November 2004, it was reported that [[Mark Mylod]] signed up to direct the feature, and that Cleese may star in the film.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dawtrey|first=Adam|title=Bigscreen goes Dahl-crazy|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117913803|accessdate=21 January 2012|newspaper=Variety|date=21 November 2004}}</ref> In October 2006, after the executive/regime changes at Disney, the project moved to [[Working Title Films|Working Title]] and [[Universal Studios|Universal]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Dawtrey|first=Adam|title=Working Title takes reality check|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117952380|accessdate=21 January 2012|newspaper=Variety|date=22 October 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Kirk DeMicco: Monkey Business|url=http://totalscifionline.com/interviews/2236-kirk-demicco-monkey-business|accessdate=21 January 2012|newspaper=Total Sci-Fi Online|date=15 July 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226095434/http://totalscifionline.com/interviews/2236-kirk-demicco-monkey-business|archivedate=26 February 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> By January 2012, the official site of Vanguard Animation stated that [[Conrad Vernon]], the director of ''[[Shrek 2]]'' and ''[[Monsters vs. Aliens]]'', would direct the film.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Twits|url=http://www.vanguardanimation.com/images/eleven.jpg|work=Vanguard Animation|accessdate=21 January 2012}}</ref>
==TV series== *An animated series based on ''The Twits'', part of an "animated series event" based on Roald Dahl's books, is being devolped by Netflix.<ref>https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/netflixs-new-roald-dahl-animated-13652537</ref> ==Relations to other Roald Dahl books== * A monkey named [[Muggle-Wump]] also appears in ''[[The Enormous Crocodile]]''. A monkey bearing resemblance to [[Quentin Blake]]'s illustration of the same character also appears in ''[[The Giraffe and the Pelly and Me]]''. * A [[Roly-Poly Bird]] likewise makes an appearance in ''[[The Enormous Crocodile]]'' and is also to be found in ''[[Dirty Beasts]]''. * Certain things within the book, such as Mr. Twit's beard, "Wormy Spaghetti" and bird pie, appear within ''Roald Dahl's Revolting Recipes''.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books/about/Roald_Dahl_s_Completely_Revolting_Recipe.html?id=7NCCPgAACAAJ Roald Dahl's Completely Revolting Recipes: A Collection of Delumptious Favourites]. Random House, 2 November 2009</ref> * An extremely strong glue is also mentioned in ''[[Matilda (novel)|Matilda]]''. * A version of "The Twits" was translated by Matthew Fitt in 2008 to include Scottish language phrases, words and expressions. The book title was renamed "The Eejits" (Glasgow slang for idiots).

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2013}} '''Thomas Banyacya''' (June 2, 1909 – 1999) was a [[Hopi]] [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] traditional leader. In 1948, he was one of four Hopis (the other were [[David Monongye]], [[Dan Evehema]], and [[Dan Katchongva]]) who were named by elders to reveal Hopi traditional wisdom and teachings, including the Hopi prophecies for the future, to the general public, after the [[atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki]] in Japan.<ref name=nyt>Thomas, Robert McG., Jr. [https://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/15/us/thomas-banyacya-89-teller-of-hopi-prophecy-to-world.html "Thomas Banyacya, 89, Teller Of Hopi Prophecy to World."] ''New York Times.'' Feb 15, 1999 (retrieved Jan 28, 2011)</ref> Banyacya was a member of the Wolf, Fox, and Coyote clans.
==Background== Banyacya grew up in the village of [[Moenkopi, Arizona]] and first attended [[Sherman Indian School]] in [[Riverside, California|Riverside]], California and then [[Bacone College]] in [[Muskogee, Oklahoma|Muskogee]], Oklahoma. He lived in [[Kykotsmovi, Arizona|Kykotsmovi]], Arizona on the [[Hopi Reservation]]. During [[World War II]], Banyacya was a draft resister, who spent time in prison over seven years each time he refused to register for the draft.<ref name=nyt/>
==Death== Banyacya died on February 6, 1999 in [[Keams Canyon, Arizona|Keams Canyon]], Arizona.<ref name=nyt/>

Thomas Banyacya ''et al.'' at the United Nations * [https://books.google.com/books?id=disBZ6hgSrMC&pg=PA166&lpg=PA166&dq=%22rolling+thunder%22+banyacya&source=bl&ots=9QCTVJOqEY&sig=AMw1r-mgrjBtucrJ5eZCaBhGi-Y&hl=en&ei=8I48TfTIAonAsAOcp4z_Ag&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CC8Q6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%22rolling%20thunder%22%20banyacya&f=false Native Americans in the twentieth century By James Stuart Olson, Raymond Wilson,VNR AG, 1984] * [http://www.sonic.net/~kerry/banyacya/thomas.htm Remembering Thomas Banyacya] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110703114218/http://nuclear-free.com/english/banyacya.htm Testimony/ Thomas Banyacya Sr., World Uranium Hearings, 14 September 1992, Salzburg] * [http://banyacya.indigenousnative.org Thomas Banyacya Hopi Traditional Elder] *[http://www.wise-uranium.org/uip.html Uranium Mining and Indigenous People]

{{other people5|Tim Shaw (disambiguation){{!}}Tim Shaw}} {{BLP sources|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox NFL player |name=Tim Shaw |image= |caption= |number=97, 57, 58, 59 |position=[[Linebacker]] |birth_date={{birth date and age|1984|3|27|mf=y}} |birth_place=[[Exeter]], [[England]] |death_date= |death_place= |height_ft=6 |height_in=1 |weight_lbs=236 |high_school=[[Clarenceville High School|Livonia (MI) Clarenceville]] |college=[[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State]] |draftyear=2007 |draftround=5 |draftpick=164 |pastteams= * [[Carolina Panthers]] ({{NFL Year|2007}}) * [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] ({{NFL Year|2008}}) * [[Chicago Bears]] ({{NFL Year|2009}}–{{NFL Year|2010}}) * [[Tennessee Titans]] ({{NFL Year|2010}}–{{NFL Year|2012}}) |highlights= |statlabel1=Tackles |statvalue1=127 |statlabel2=Sacks |statvalue2=0.0 |statlabel3=Interceptions |statvalue3=0 |statlabel4=Forced fumbles |statvalue4=3 |nfl=SHA784677 }} '''Timothy Bruce Shaw''' (born March 27, 1984) is a former [[American football]] [[linebacker]] who played in the [[National Football League]]. He played [[college football]] at [[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State]] and he was drafted by the [[Carolina Panthers]] in the fifth round of the [[2007 NFL Draft]].
Shaw also played for the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]], [[Chicago Bears]] and [[Tennessee Titans]].
==College career== Tim Shaw was recruited out of Livonia Clarenceville High School as a running back. A three-star recruit, he decided to attend [[Penn State]], spurning other scholarship offers from Big Ten schools such as Michigan and Michigan State.<ref>[https://rivals.yahoo.com/footballrecruiting/football/recruiting/player-Tim-Shaw-683;_ylt=An4Cx0f2zT7Xgs.iS2AsORZDPZB4]</ref> Shaw saw extensive playing time on special teams and began earning snaps on defense. He became a starter, playing alongside [[Bednarik Award]] winning linebackers [[Paul Posluszny]] and [[Dan Connor (American football)|Dan Connor]], on what many people consider the best Penn State linebacking corps of all time. Shaw was a 2006 Academic [[All-America]]n.<ref>[http://www.gopsusports.com/pressreleases/pressrelease.cfm?anncid=11364 Press Release] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070619000323/http://www.gopsusports.com/pressreleases/pressrelease.cfm?anncid=11364 |date=2007-06-19 }}</ref>
==Professional career==
===Carolina Panthers=== In the [[2007 NFL Draft]], Shaw was drafted in the 5th round by the Carolina Panthers.
===Jacksonville Jaguars=== Shaw was signed by the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] on November 26, 2008, and appeared in three games for the Jaguars that season. He spent the 2009 preseason in Jacksonville's camp before being released on September 5, 2009.<ref name="bearsinterested">{{cite web | url = http://profootball.scout.com/a.z?s=127&p=9&c=2&cid=898901&nid=4302175&fhn=1 | title = Bears Looking At Shaw | first = Ed | last = Thompson | publisher = ScoutNFLNetwork.com | date = 2009-09-14}}</ref>
===Chicago Bears=== The [[Chicago Bears]] signed Shaw on September 14, 2009 after opening-week injuries to linebackers [[Brian Urlacher]] and [[Pisa Tinoisamoa]] depleted their linebacking corps.<ref name="bearsinterested"/> He set a club record for special teams tackles with 30 after an 8 tackle performance with a forced fumble and recovery against the Detroit Lions (Jan 3, 2010).<ref name="bearsstrecord">{{cite web | url = http://www.chicagobreakingsports.com/2010/01/shaw-sets-club-record-for-special-teams-tackles.html | title = Shaw sets club record for special-teams tackles | first = Brad | last = Biggs | publisher = chicagobreakingsports.com | date = 2010-01-04}}</ref> On January 27, 2010, the [[USA Today]] announced that Shaw had made its All-Joe Team, honoring the NFL's unsung and underrated players.<ref>[http://www.chicagobears.com/news/NewsStory.asp?story_id=6511]</ref>
===Tennessee Titans=== On September 5, 2010, Shaw was claimed off waivers by the [[Tennessee Titans]]. He played in 48 games over three seasons for the Titans and was their special teams captain in 2011 and 2012. He was released during final cuts on August 31, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lomas|first1=Will|title=NFL roster cuts: Titans release Rusty Smith, Doyle, Shaw, and Mooney.|url=http://www.musiccitymiracles.com/2013/8/31/4679336/nfl-roster-cuts-titans-release-rusty-smith-doyle-shaw-and-mooney|publisher=musiccitymiracles.com|accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref>
==Personal life== Shaw is a [[Christianity|Christian]]. Shaw has said that his faith is "... the foundation of who I am."<ref>{{cite tweet|user=TShawsTruth|author=Tim Shaw|number=318345021227163650|date=31 March 2013|title=Christ is risen!!! What else is there to say? This is the foundation of who I am.}}</ref> Shaw has gone on two [[Mission (Christianity)|mission]] trips to Costa Rica and two mission trips to Haiti.<ref>{{cite web|title=Former Titans Football Player Responds to Cut from Team|url=http://athletesinaction.org/news/former-titans-football-player-responds-to-cut-from-team|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140821054758/http://athletesinaction.org/news/former-titans-football-player-responds-to-cut-from-team|archivedate=2014-08-21|df=}}</ref>
Shaw is close friends with former [[tight end]] [[Kevin Boss]].<ref name="XAM">{{cite web | url = http://profootball.scout.com/2/938004.html | title = NFL Playoff Picks: Boss vs. Shaw | publisher = [[Scout.com]] | last = Thompson | first = Ed | date = 2010-01-15}}</ref> The two are represented by the same firm, XAM Sports, and were roommates while training in Florida prior to the [[2007 NFL Draft]].<ref name="XAM"/> Shaw attended Boss' July 4, 2009, wedding.<ref name="XAM"/>
Shaw is reportedly a [[Jigsaw puzzle]] enthusiast.<ref name="XAM"/>
On August 19, 2014, Shaw revealed in a video that he has [[ALS]] disease. He then dumped a bucket of ice water over himself as part of the [[Ice Bucket Challenge]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kuharsky|first1=Paul|title=Tim Shaw reveals ALS diagnosis|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/11378896/tim-shaw-former-tennessee-titans-special-teamer-reveals-als-diagnosis|website=espn.com|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref> In 2017 Shaw was invited to speak to the current [[2017 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State football team]] he spoke about his challenges after his diagnosis and spoke about his time playing football at Penn States and his experience in the NFL. His speech resonated with head coach [[James Franklin (American football coach)|James Franklin]] who posted his speech on his [[Twitter]] account which gained national attention. On November 18, 2017 Shaw was the honorary captain for Penn State's game vs the [[Nebraska Cornhuskers]]. Shaw was honored with a video tribute and standing ovation by fans along with both teams.

'''Unreported missing''' (also known as '''Missing Missing'''<ref name="ref1">http://hsx.sagepub.com/cgi/reprint/11/4/319</ref> or '''Kids off the Grid'''<ref name="ref2">{{cite web|url=http://www.outpostforhope.org |title=Outpost For Hope |publisher=Outpost For Hope |date=2012-01-15 |accessdate=2012-01-20}}</ref>) describes persons who cannot be found, yet have not been or cannot be reported as [[missing persons]] to [[Law enforcement agency|law enforcement]], specifically the [[National Crime Information Center]] database of missing persons in the United States. The term applies whether the missing person is a child or an adult.
==Explanations== One reason unreported missing persons may not be formally listed as missing is that those over the [[age of majority]] can be "voluntarily missing." Barring evidence of criminality or being a danger to oneself, [[privacy]] and [[confidentiality]] laws generally protect the rights of those who elect to remain out of contact with family or friends. If an adult unreported missing person is located in such an instance, the police are not obligated to inform the family of the missing person's whereabouts.
According to Outpost For Hope,<ref name="ref2"/> people can become unreported missing for a variety of reasons, including:
* the lost/missing person may be estranged from family or friends; * law enforcement may not take a "missing person" report; * the lost/missing person may be in the country illegally; * the person may be an unknown dependent child of unreported missing adults or teens; or * the person might be the victim of an undiscovered crime.
Another example is of children born to homeless or drug addicted mothers. These children are sometimes not registered anywhere and can become victims of crime without any of their other relatives or local agencies knowing. Other children who go missing but are unreported are often runaway [[foster children]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/MISSING+KID+CRISIS+DCFS+FINDS+ONLY+A+FEW+RUNAWAYS,+ABDUCTEES-a094623421 |title=Missing Kid Crisis Dcfs Finds Only A Few Runaways, Abductees. - Free Online Library |publisher=Thefreelibrary.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-20}}</ref> or children who are neglected or whose files are simply cases fumbled by police.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shns.com/shns/g_index2.cfm?action=detail&pk=MISSING-05-10-05 |title=Scripps Howard News Service |publisher=Shns.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-20}}</ref>
Someone can also become an Unreported Missing person through a victim of an exploitative crime, being involved in human trafficking or prostitution. A study by Professor Kenna Quinet states, "The most successful serial killers know to select the unmissed as victims if they intend to kill for an extended period of time".<ref name="ref1"/> In her study she refers to serial killers targeting transient people because they are not easily missed, as well as people in institutionalized care.
==Risks==
Being unreported puts a person at a higher risk of exploitation than a person who is reported missing. There are many different outcomes or ways in which a person can be lost or "[[wikt:off the grid|off the grid]]". These outcomes include situations like being mentally ill and lost among the homeless.<ref>Readers Digest Article http://www.rd.com/content/founder-of-outpost-for-hope</ref> When this happens, a person could very well be [[mentally ill]] or have a drug problem, go into the streets, cannot be reported missing by their family because they have a history of disappearing and then be the victim of murder or [[human trafficking]]. The family never sees them again and even if their body is found, the police have no way of tracking the person to their family as they are not listed in any formal missing database.
==Notable cases== * [[Death of Barbara Precht|Barbara Precht]], discovered in 2006 and was not identified until late 2014. She was never reported missing by her husband. *[[Murder of Anjelica Castillo|Anjelica Castillo]], discovered in 1991 and was not reported missing due to her mother's fears of deportation, as her family were illegal immigrants. *[[Death of Jason Callahan|Jason Callahan]], discovered in 1995, not reported missing until 2015, as his family did not know what jurisdiction to report his disappearance to and thought he may have gone to live on his own and not wanted contact. *[[Murder of Atcel Olmedo|Atcel Olmedo]], discovered in 2005 and was not reported missing because of complications with his abusive stepfather. *[[Murder of Marcia King|Marcia King]], discovered in 1981 and was not reported missing due to a transient lifestyle.
==References== {{reflist|2}} [[Category:Missing people| ]] [[Category:Unidentified decedents| ]]

''[[Unreserved]]'', February 4, 2018. == Background == A member of the [[Arikara|Arikara tribe]], Vizin moved to Los Angeles from [[North Dakota]], where she lived at the [[Fort Berthold Reservation]], which is a part of the [[Three Affiliated Tribes]].{{Cite news|url=https://hornetapp.com/stories/vizin-drag-queen/|title=This Native American Drag Queen Lost 500 Pounds and Became a Top 40 Artist|date=2018-01-03|work=Hornet Stories|access-date=2018-01-15|language=en-US}} She began her career in [[Drag show|drag]] in the year 2007, where she took part in her first gig.{{cite web|url=https://almeida.co.uk/on-being-carmen-a-conversation-with-viktoria-vizin |title=On Being Carmen: A Conversation with Viktoria Vizin | News | Almeida | About Us |publisher=Almeida |date=2015-05-23 |accessdate=2018-01-15}}{{cite web|url=https://thepridela.com/2017/12/west-hollywood-based-singer-vizin-making-us-feel-mighty-real/ |title=West Hollywood-based Singer VIZIN is Making Us Feel Mighty Real |publisher=The Pride LA |date= |accessdate=2018-01-15}} In 2016, she released a single titled "I Was Born This Way". It is a remake of the 1975 song by [[Valentino (singer)|Valentino]].{{cite web|last=Artavia |first=David |url=https://www.advocate.com/current-issue/2017/11/16/two-spirit-changes-face-drag-pop |title=Two-Spirit Changes Face of Drag-Pop |publisher=Advocate.com |date=2017-11-16 |accessdate=2018-01-15}}{{cite web|url=https://music.allaccess.com/an-interview-with-the-native-american-drag-pop-recording-artist-vizin/ |title=An Interview With The Native American Drag Pop Recording Artist, VIZIN! | All Access Music |publisher=Music.allaccess.com |date= |accessdate=2018-01-15}}{{cite web|author=Eileen Shapiro, ContributorEileen |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/interview-and-video-premier-vizin_us_5924a6fbe4b09c5b6bf92cb6 |title=Interview and Video Premier: VIZIN | HuffPost |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2018-01-15}} == Discography == === Charted singles === {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" scope="col" style="width:22em;" |Title ! rowspan="2" scope="col" style="width:1em;" |Year ! scope="col" |Peak chart positions |- ! scope="col" style="width:3em;font-size:85%;" |[[Dance Club Songs|US]]

{{for|the 1940 film|Women in War}} The experiences of '''women in war''' have been diverse. Historically women have played a major role on the [[home front]]. By the 18th century, some women accompanied armies assigned combat missions, usually handling roles such as cooking and laundry. Nursing became a major role starting in the middle 19th century. The main role in World War I (1914-1918) was employment in munitions factories, farming, and other roles to replace men drafted for the army. Women played an important role in making the system of food rationing work. World War II (1939-1945) marked a decisive turning point, With millions of women handling important homefront roles, such as working in munitions factories and otherwise replacing drafted men. Volunteer roles expanded. The most romantic new change was millions of women in regular military units. Typically they handled clerical roles so that men could be released for combat. Some women (especially in the Soviet Union, Germany, and Britain) were assigned limited combat roles, especially in anti-aircraft units, where they shot down enemy bombers while at the same time being safe from capture. Underground and resistance movements made extensive use of women in support roles. Reaction set in after 1945, and the roles allowed to women was sharply reduced in all major armies. Restarting in the 1970s, women played an increasing role in the military of major nations, including by 2005 roles as combat pilots. The new combat roles were highly controversial for many reasons including differences in physical capabilities of the sexes <ref>{{cite web|author=Brad Knickerbocker|title=Just three pull-ups: Too many for women in the Marine Corps?|url=https://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Military/2014/0104/Just-three-pull-ups-Too-many-for-women-in-the-Marine-Corps|publisher=CS Monitor|date=January 4, 2014|accessdate=October 10, 2017}}</ref> and issues of gender identity for both women and men.<ref>Barton C. Hacker and Margaret Vining, eds. ''A Companion to Women's Military History'' (2012)</ref>
